We were given a long Hex string, while the problem title was:

>Layers of Disguise (400)

```

```

Googling a bit let us know that `1F8B08` is the gzip magic string, so we converted it to a gzip file:

`xxd -r -p problem.txt step1.gz`

Then uncompressing the gz file:

`gunzip -c step1.gz > step2.txt`

We get output as a binary string:

```

```

Converting this binary to text using the [xlate tool](http://home.paulschou.net/tools/xlate/):

``

Clearly, a base64 encoded string. Decoding it:

`cat step3.txt |base64 -d >step4.txt`

```
+ACYAIw-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x35+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x32+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x31+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x31+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x32+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x31+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x31+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x32+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x35+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x35+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x32+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x32+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x35+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x31+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x32+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x30+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x32+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x31+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x35+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x34+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x34+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x34+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x34+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x37+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x34+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x36+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x34+ADsAJgAj-x25+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADsAJgAj-x33+ADs-
```
We were stuck here for a while. Searching for the substrings `ACYAIw` and `ADsAJgAj` led us to
some brazillian hacking group with a wordpress exploit, but we could not think of a way to
reach the key from the various hacked websites we encountered. Ultimately, it struck someone
to treat the digits as numeric character references:

```
&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x35;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x33;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x32;&#x25;&#x36;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x33;&#x25;&#x36;&#x31;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x36;&#x31;&#x25;&#x33;&#x32;&#x25;&#x36;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x36;&#x31;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x36;&#x31;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x33;&#x25;&#x33;&#x32;&#x25;&#x36;&#x35;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x36;&#x35;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x32;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x36;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x32;&#x25;&#x36;&#x35;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x31;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x32;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x30;&#x25;&#x33;&#x32;&#x25;&#x36;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x36;&#x31;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x36;&#x35;&#x25;&#x33;&#x34;&#x25;&#x33;&#x33;&#x25;&#x33;&#x34;&#x25;&#x36;&#x33;&#x25;&#x33;&#x33;&#x25;&#x33;&#x34;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x36;&#x34;&#x25;&#x33;&#x37;&#x25;&#x33;&#x36;&#x25;&#x33;&#x34;&#x25;&#x36;&#x33;&#x25;&#x33;&#x34;&#x25;&#x33;&#x33;
```

Opening this in the (`step5.html`) gives us:

```
%36%37%37%35%36%33%36%37%32%66%33%61%36%61%32%66%36%61%36%61%36%33%32%65%36%36%36%65%37%32%36%37%37%36%36%66%32%65%36%31%36%32%37%30%32%66%37%61%36%65%34%33%34%63%33%34%36%64%37%36%34%63%34%33
```

Clearly an escape sequence. Running the following in chrome console:

```js
unescape("%36%37%37%35%36%33%36%37%32%66%33%61%36%61%32%66%36%61%36%61%36%33%32%65%36%36%36%65%37%32%36%37%37%36%36%66%32%65%36%31%36%32%37%30%32%66%37%61%36%65%34%33%34%63%33%34%36%64%37%36%34%63%34%33")
```

`677563672f3a6a2f6a6a632e666e7267766f2e6162702f7a6e434c346d764c43`

We tried submitting this, but to no avail. In fact we spent an entire night assuming
that this was the right answer and that it was an issue on the organizing side.

Next day, we tried converting the hex to ascii:

`xxd -r -p step7.txt step8.txt`

This gives us:

`gucg/:j/jjc.fnrgvo.abp/znCL4mvLC`

Looks like an http address, but with some change. Trying `rot13`:

`cat step8.txt |rot13 > step9.txt` leads us to:

`thpt/:w/wwp.saetib.noc/maPY4ziYP`

That looks like an HTTP address. Its basically a digraph-swap-cipher (I invented the name).
Exchanging letters in pairs gives us `http://pastebin.com/Pa4YizPY`. Opening the URL
gives us the final answer: `3f78eb8523986d7d986053ba5a1dae1ed5f13d41`.

All things considered, this level involved about 10 "layers of disguise".
